coredata.dc:title: The d and f resonances in the core level absorption spectra of TeF6
coredata.dc:creator: Tse, John S.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The post-edge resonant features observed in the Te p and d core level absorption spectra of TeF6 have been characterized with stabilized bound state and continuum multiple scattering Xα calculations. The nature of the resonances above the Te 4p edge is similar to that observed in SF6 and can be attributed to excitations into quasibound channels with substantial kd character. The localization of the continuum channel is due to strong interactions between the Te d and F p and d orbitals. The origin of the resonances above the Te 4d edge is different. It is better described as a manifestation of the atomic-like d→kf delayed onset as a consequence of the Te centrifugal potential.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 163, number 4,5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 17November 1989 THE d AND f RESONANCES IN THE CORE LEVEL ABSORPTION SPECTRA OF TeF6 * John S. TSE Division of Chemistry, NationalResearch Council of Canada, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada K1A 0R9 Received 15August1989 The post-edge resonant features observed in the Te p and d core level absorption spectra of TeF6 have been characterized with stabi]ized bound state and continuum multiple scattering Xcs calculations. The nature of the resonances above the Te 4p edge is similar to that observed in SF6 and can be attributed to excitations into quasibound channels with substantial kd character. The localization of the continuum channel is due to strong interactions between the Te d and F p and d orbitais. The origin of the resonances above the Te 4d edge is different. It is better described as a manifestation of the atomic-like d i kf delayed Onset as a consequence of the Te centrifugal potential. 1. Introduction The study of resonant enhancement in the inten- sity in photoionization and photoabsorption exper- iments has been of topical interest [1]. This phe- nomenon was first observed in the core level photoabsorplion spectra of highly fluorinated main group compounds [2,3]. Due to recent advances in synchrotron radiation and electron energy loss spec- troscopy (EELS), this phenomenon has now been identified in many other molecules. The study of the intensity enhancement also has some practical sig- nificance as it has been shown that the energy of the excitation can be related to the structure of the mol- ecule [4]. In an one-electron model, according to Fermi s golden rule, the enhancement in the cross section in absorption and ionization is due to an increase in the transition moment involving the ground and excited states. Under certain conditions, the scattering of photoelectrons by the anisotropic coupling of the molecular field will result in the localization of the continuum channel. The overlap between the quasi- bound channel with the ground state wavefunction will then be increased. For the highly fluorinated compounds, it has been suggested that a potential barrier can be generated by the electron-rich fluorine * Published as NRCC 30529. atoms [3}. As a result of the repulsive interactions, the outgoing electron is trapped temporarily in- side the molecular core and becomes quasibound. This interpretation is similar in spirit to the centrif- ugal potential in the atoms which have been shown to be responsible for the delayed-onset in core ex- citations [5]. Since the localization process is de- pendent on the shape of the potential, this phenom- enon has been called shape resonance [1,3]. An alternative explanation based on molecular orbital theory [1,6] has been proposed to rationalize the en- hancement processes. The strong excitation is at- tributed to an electronic transition into a spatially localized orbital embedded in the continuum. The localized orbital can have antibonding or Rydberg valence mixed character [1,6,7 J. Several causes of resonant enhancement have been evaluated in a re- cent theoretical investigation. It was shown, through a comprehensive study on the valence level pho- toionization cross section of XeF2 [7,8], that the shape resonance and the molecular orbital descrip- tion are complementary and both processes can con- tribute to the change in the cross section of excita- tions [9]. Traditionally, the study of shape resonance has been concentrated on highly fluorinated compounds, in particular, SF6 110]. In the inner shell absorption spectra of SF6, two strong peaks were observed above the S 2p edge but no discernible structure was found 392 Volume 163, number 4,5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 17 November 1989 in the S Is post-edge region. Lt is easy to assign the peaks to excitations into orbitais of g symmetry. Mo- lecular orbital calculations [11,12] showed that the localization of the unoccupied S d orbitais is a result of the antibonding interactions with the p orbitaIs [11,12 J of the F ligands. Hence, the resonances re- semble atomic p 6d transitions and can acquire large oscillator strengths. This explanation, however, has been questioned recently and the anomalous inten- sity of the peaks was attributed to many-electron processes [13]. The new assignment is unsatisfac- tory in many ways. A more thorough experimental [14] and theoretical [15] assessment on the S 2p photoabsorption spectrum in SF6 will be presented elsewhere. In order to gain more insight into the na- ture of the shape resonance phenomenon, experi- mental studies have been extended to the analogous SeF6 [16]. A similar enhancement in the valence level photoionization cross sections was observed. More recently, the inner shell absorption spectra of SeF6 and TeF6 have been measured using high res- olution electron energy loss spectroscopy [17]. The most exciting observation is the presence of rich res- onance features above the Te d core levels. These features have been tentatively assigned to the atomic d s f transitions [17]. The objective of this investi- gation is to characterize and quantify these obser- vations with theoretical continuum multiple scatter- ing Xa calculations. In particular, the Te 4p and 4d post-edge absorption spectra will be studied in detail. 2. Computational details The continuum multiple scattering Xa (MS Xa) method developed by Dehmer and Dill [18,19] and independently by Davenport [20] was used in the present study. The MS Xce is a first principle one- electron model based on the density functional the- ory [211. The approximations involved with the method are the muffin-tin partitioning of the mol- ecule into atomic spheres to facilitate the solution of the molecular Schrodinger equation and in the choice of the exchange parameters [2 11. In the continuum calculations [18 20], important effects of photo- electron scattering through anisotropic coupling by the molecular potential are duly taken. into account [19]. Although MS Xs calculations are not ex- pected to give quantitative results for comparison with experimental spectra [19], important features in the photoabsorption and photoionization spectra, such as the Cooper minimum and resonant enhance- ment, are always faithfully reproduced [19]. The MS Xa method has been applied to many calculations of the valence level ionization cross sections with very favourable results [1,22]. Application of this method to core level absorption and ionization has also met with considerable success [9,23,24]. As mentioned earlier, the primary aim of the present theoretical study is to better characterize the continuum states and not to provide accurate assignments to the ex- perimental spectra. Moreover, relativistic effects probably will be important for the description of the electronic properties of the TeF6. A relativistic for- mulation of the continuum XOE model is not yet available. The atomic and outer sphere radii and the ex- change parameters were taken from a previous cal- culation on TeF6 [25]. In the ground state calcula- tion, the partial wave expansions were truncated at lz~ 5, 4 and 2 for the outersphere, Te and F spheres respectively. In the continuum calculations, the ex- pansion was extended to 1=6, 5 and 3 respectively. A latter tail [261 was added to the molecular poten- tial during the SCF procedure to correct for the asymptotic behaviour. In th SCF calculations, the Te 4p level was treated as core but the Te 4d are in- cluded in the valence level. The absorption cross sec- tion of the Te 4p and 4d were calculated from the respective transition state potential. All symmetry- allowed transitions were considered in the calcula- tions. In h symmetry, the dipole allowed contin- uum channels for 4p (t1~) excitations are ka~, keg, kt~ and ktsg. The degenerate Te 4d split into t2g and eg orbitais in an octahedral field. The kt1~ and kt2~ channels are accessible from both the t2~ and e8 or- bitals. In addition, the ka2~, and ke~ are symmetry allow ed for the t28 initial state only. Since the nature of a continuum channel is primarily determined by the molecular field and is independent on the initial orbital [24,271, and the t28 absorption excitations include all the symmetry allowed continuum chan- nels for eg, only the results for the t~ component of the Te 4d will be discussed in detail. The nature of the continuum channels is charac- terized by two methods. The eigeuphase sum is a 393 Volume 163, number 4,5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 17 November 1989 measure of the phase shift of the photoelectron due to the scatterings by the molecular potential [28]. For a noninteracting photoelectron, the continuum wavefunction is a plane wave and the eigenphase sum is a smooth function of its kinetic energy. If the photoelectron were strongly scattered by the molec- ular potential, as in the resonance, the continuum channel would be signified by a rapid change in the eigenphase sum. One of the advantages of the MS Xc~ method is the elimination of the finite atomic basis set by the use of partial wave expansion [21]. Unfortunately, the numerical nature of the calcula- tions has created difficulties in the interpretation of the wavefunctions. It is possible to give a pictorial description of the continuum channel [29], how- ever, at times it is difficult to associate the electron density with the individual atomic component. In order to get a better understanding of the composi- tion of the continuum orbitaIs, an alternative ap- proach of stabilizing the empty levels by placing the molecule in a positive potential was used. This sta- bilization method [30] has yielded reasonable re- sults in the characterization of the continuum orbit- aIs in temporary negative ion (TNI) [31] and photoionization spectroscopy [7]. To ensure the im- position of positive potential would not create arti- fact energy levels, test calculations using electronic charge varied from +2e to +4e were performed. In all cases, the composition and the corrected binding energy for the empty orbitais with substantial va- lence character are not strongly affected by the choice of the positive potential. Most of the results reported here were obtained with a 3+ electronic charge uni- formly distributed on the Watson sphere. As a result, the energy eigenvalues spectrum is shifted by 15.5 eV to lower energy (2q/r Ry; q = electronic charge, r=outersphere radius) permitting the low lying con- tinuum orbitais to be analysed in the usual manner as it was bound. 3. Results and discussion 3.1. Te 4p core level The theoretical Te 4p post-edge absorption spec- trum of TeF6 is shown in fig, la. The Te 4p ioni- zation cross section is predicted to be very weak [32]. The theoretical spectrum shows two broad peaks. The first peak located 7 eV above the ionization thresh- old has a weak maximum. The intensity of the sec- ond peak is slightly stronger and is found at 20 eV above the threshold. The eigenphase sum for the symmetry-allowed continuum channels for the Te ~4p excitation is plotted in fig. lb. The peaks can be as- signed to shape resonances according to the criteria suggested by Kreile et al. [33]. The lower energy peak is due to a resonance in the kt28 channel. The eigen- phase sum of the continuum channel changed by 0.7ic over an energy range of 4 eV. Similarly, the higher energy peak can be traced back to an e8 resonance as the eigenphase sum of this continuum channel has changed rapidly over a small energy range. The other dipole allowed kaig and t18 channels make negligible contribution to the cross section and, according to the behaviour of their eigenphase sums, are only weakly interacting with the molecular potential. MS Xa stabilization calculations give a clearer de- scription of the resonances. Interspersed among the t40 Photon Energy / eV Fig. 1. Theoretical Te 4p (top) cross section and (bottom) ei- genphase sum for the continuum channels in TeF6. 394 Volume 163, number 4,5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 17November 1989 densely packed Rydberg empty levels, two orbitais of significant atomic Te and F and intersphere charges can be found in an energy search of the t28 symmetry. The first orbital has an orbitai energy of 1,08 Ry and charge distributions: g0~1 = 43% (d), q11,~ = 45%, qT~= 1% (d) and q~= 11% (p) with the majority an- gular character given in parentheses. The second or- bitai is located at 0.76 Ry with q0~~=55% (d, g), q~,,~=28%, qT~=tO% (d) and q~=7% (p, d). After the correction for the stabilization potential, the ap- parent orbital energies become 0.06 Ry (+0.83 eV) and 0.38 Ry (+ 5.2 eV), respectively. The first or- bital is very close to the ionization threshold. The second orbital is located in the continuum and can be correlated with the 7 eV t28 resonance channel predicted by the continuum MS Xa calculations. The orbital energy estimated from the stabilization method is reasonably close to the exact value ob- tained from continuum calculations. Contour dia- grams for the wavefunction of the two orbitais are depicted in fig. 2. The first orbital shows strong an- tibonding interactions between the atomic spheres, and the molecule is enclosed by a diffuse orbital of d symmetry. In contrast, the second orbital shows strong bonding interactions between the Te and F d orbitals. However, the d wave is much more com- pact with the charge density concentrated around the molecular interior. Furthermore, there is a nodal surface separating the molecular core from the out- side region. This nodal structure is not present in the first orbital. These observations have an important significance. It demonstrates that as the orbital (photoelectron) energy increases, the d wave be- comes more contracted with commitant develop- ment of a nodal structure in the wavefunction. This description corresponds exactly to the observation made in the continuum calculations. The large ei- genphase shift in the t28 continuum channel (~ n) is an indication of the penetration of an antinode into the potential barrier [3]. As a result, the amplitude of the continuum wavefunction in the molecular re- gion is greatly enhanced and so is the absorption cross section. The energy of the e6 resonance is 20 eV above threshold, the characterization of the resonant chan- nel using the stabilization method will require a charge of + 6.0e units. As a result of the large pos- itive potential, a greater number of empty levels shifted into the bound state. As the density of the virtual state becomes so dense, the numerical pro- cedure for the energy search becomes unreliable. Be- cause of this technical difficulty, the e8 resonance is not studied by the stabilizalion method. Further- more, recent experiment [13] and calculation [12] have also shown that the e8 resonance may not be well described by an independent-particle state. The theoretical results presented here share many similarities to those for SF6. Two strong peaks have Fig. 2.Contour map for the t2~ wavefunctions, (a) non-resonant and (b) resonant obtained from the stabilization method (see text). The unit of the coordinates in bohr. 395 17 November 1989 Volume 163, number 4,5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS been observed in the post-edge region of the exper- imental S 2p spectrum [10,16,34]. The positions of the peaks are located at 2.7 and 15.3 eV above the ionization threshold [34]. The theoretical results obtained from SCF [11,12], SCF/C1 [14] and MS Xa [14] are consistent with each other. All calcu- lations predict two strong excitations into orbitais of predominantly S d character. The low energy peak can be assigned to the S 2p (t~~) *t26 transition and the higher energy peak to S 2p *e8. Analysis of the wavefunction of the excited states show that the S d orbitais are bounded by the out-of-phase interac- tions with the F 2p and the in-phase interactions with the F d orbitais perpendicular to the S F bonds [11,121. It should be noted that the atomic wave- functions on F have been restricted to valence s and p orbitais in the MO calculation [11]. However, the resemblance between the wavefunction of the ex- cited t28 orbital in SF6 [12] and that observed here for TeF6 is remarkable. The observation further sub- stantiates the equivalence in the molecular orbital and MS Xa description of the resonance phenom- enon [9]. It also shows that the stabilization method [301 is able to give reliable information on the char- acter of the excited states. In a way, the splitting of the empty S and Ted or- bitais due to the influence of the F ligands is anal- ogous to the well known ligand field splittings in transition metal complexes [35]. It is important to point out that the basic mechanisms for the splitting are fundamentally different and the physical model developed for ligand field theory may not be directly applicable. The splitting of the d levels in the con- tinuum is partly due to molecular symmetry, but more importantly, the orthogonal interactions with the ligands lead to a renormalization of the d wave- function. Having realized the differences, it is of some interest to apply the existing theory to get an order of magnitude estimate on the t2g and e8 splitting in the hexafluorides. In the point charge approxima- tion, the ligand field splitting for the d orbitais in an octahedral molecule is lO(r4)d/6R5, where R is the interatomic distance [35]. Rough estimates8 of <r4>d for neutral S 3d and Te Sd gave a 12g and e8 ~ The r4>d values were obtained with atomic Hartree Fock Slater calculations. <r4)d for S6~ is 10.3 au and for Te64 is 61.8 au. splitting greater than the separation observed in the absorption spectra. A more reasonable agreement was found when the <r4>d values for the S6~ and Te6~ ion were used. In the latter case, the t2g e8 splitting in SF6 and TeF6 is estimated to be 2.0 and 5.7 eV, respectively. In agreement with the theoretical prediction, the Te 4p post-edge spectrum is very weak and shows no discernible feature [17]. In contrast, distinct ab- sorption bands centered at 4 and 16 eV above the ionization threshold can be observed in the Te 3p spectrum. These features have been assigned to sym- metry forbidden transitions. However, according to our calculations, these bands may as well be corre- lated to the excitations into the Te d dominated t28 and e6 orbitals. More refined calculations and an im- provement in the experimental condition to elimi- nate non-dipole-allowed transitions using synchro- tron radiation are required before a more definitive assignment can be made. 3.2. Te 4d Resonant-like structures above the ionization edge of both the Te 4d and Te 3d levels have been ob- served in TeF6 [17]. The rich features in the ab- sorption spectra can only be understood by invoking transitions into f-type continuum orbitais [17]. In particular, the three broad peaks above the threshold have been tentatively assigned to the ligand field split f-type t1~, ~ and t2~, transitions, It is of interest to investigate whether the origin of the post-edge struc- tures in the Te d spectra is caused by similar inter- actions with the ligands as in the p level spectra. The MS Xa absorption cross section for the t28 component of the Te 4d level is shown in fig. 3a. The eg component, which is not shown here, has a similar profile but is weaker in intensity. The major contri- bution to the cross section is derived from transi- tions into the kt2~ and kt10 channels which are both accessible from the 12g and e8 initial orbitai. The the- oretical cross section is dominated by two peaks at 67 and 72 eV, which are 12 and 17 eV above the Te 4d edge, respectively. The eigenphase sums of the corresponding continuum channels are given in fig. 3h. It is clearly shown that in the energy region 65 to 75 eV, the ka2~, kt1~ and kt20 channels are in res- onance. Although, there is also a change in the ei- 396 volume i 63, number 4,5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 17November 1989 -o o L) Q) Q) Q) Q) o L) U 5) u -c o o 5) Fig. 3. Theoretical Te 4d (top) cross section and (bottom) ei- genphase sum for the continuum channels in TeF6. genphase sum in the ke0 channel, it is not large enough to be classified as resonance [33]. In an octahedral field, the f orbitais transforni as a2~, t1,, and t2~. Since there is no combination of the iigand orbitais of a2,, symmetry and the f orbitaIs are pointing directly into the F atoms in t1,, symmetry, simple ligand field considerations would predict the following energy ordering, a2,, < t~,, <t ~ The small calculated splittings of the f orbitais indicates that the interactions between the f channel and the ii- gands are small. Stabilized empty orbitaIs with sig- nificant valence character and energy close to the exact continuum resonant energy can be readily identified from the energy search. For the t2,, and a20 symmetries, the appropriate orbitais are located at 10 and li eV, respectively. The charge distribu- tion for the a2,, orbital is, q0,,t=84% (f), q1~5~5%, qTe= 10% (f), qQ)=0.4% (d); and for the t2,, orbital, q0~1=63% (f), q~5_~ 11%, qTe= 18% (f), q1~=7% (p, d). For the t ~ symmetry, an orbital of considerable valence character is found at 14.7 eV with electron populations, q0,,, = 72% (p, f), ~ 0.6%, ~Te = 22% (f), qQ)=6 Io (s, p, d). The closeness of the a2~ and t21, orbitais and their 4 eV separation from the higher energy t1,, orbital are in good accord with results ob- tained from the more exact continuum calculations. For each symmetry, a comparison of the wavefunc- tions of the resonant channels with an empty va- lence orbital preceeding the resonance is displayed in fig. 4. The off-resonant orbital in a2~ symmetry is a dif- fuse pure f wave with no contribution from the Ii- gands. This observation is not unexpected, as al- ready indicated, there is no combination of the ligands p orbitaIs which transforms as a2~. At the resonance, the f wave contracts around the molec- ular region and a nodal surface divides the space into an inner and an outer region. A more vivid display of the localization of the f wave is given in fig. 5. The 3-D contour maps show strong resemblance to the eigenchannel plots for the off- and on-f-resonant in molecular nitrogen [29]. Resonances in the other symmetry allowed t1,, and 120 channels of TeF6 also 85 show a similar behaviour. In the non-resonant re- gime, the wavefunctions are generally diffuse but be- come increasingly localized when the energy is close to the resonance. Comparison of figs. 2 and 4 reveals a distinct dif- ference in the nature of the interactions leading to the localization of the d and f wavefunctions. Per- haps, with the exception of the t11, orbitais (note the strong p symmetry in the outersphere region), the Te F interactions are much weaker in the f reso- nance. The f wave penetrates gradually into the mo- lecular interior as the energy increases. This obser- vation is analogous to that observed in the heavy atoms where the continuum wavefunction is local- ized by the centrifugal potential [5,36]. The com- petition between repulsive centrifugal forces and at- tractive Coulombic forces creates a barrier and divides the atom into two regions an inner attrac- tive region and an outer region where the potential decays exponentially [37]. At low kinetic energy, the continuum f channel is excluded from the inner re- gion and behaves like a plane wave in the outer re- gion. At appropriate energies, the f continuum chan- nel penetrates into the inner region and becomes quasibound. The localization of the wavefunction results in good overlap between the initial state and os so es 70 75 Photon Energy / eV 80 397 Volume 163, number 4,5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 17November 1989 Fig. 4. Contour map for the a21 (tOP); t2u (middle) and t1,, wavefunctions obtained from the stabilization method (see text). The non- resonant orbitais are shown on the left and the resonant orbitaIs on the right. The unit of the coordinates in bohr. - 7.5 -5 25 0 2.5 5 7.S -7.5 5 as o as s 398 Volume t63, number 4,5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 17November 1989 the cross section for the transition will be enhanced. The delayed onset of the transition intensity maxi- mum is well known in atomic spectroscopy [5]. The width, intensity and position of the delayed-onset maximum is very sensitive to the potential [36]. For instance, in XeF2, the Xe 4d ~kf delayed onset has been observed at 22.6 eV [81, which is 4 eV lower than the atomic value t 38]. On the other hand, the band width in the XeF2 molecule is much narrower than that in the atom. From the experimental and theoretical evidence gathered here, it is very likely that the resonant structures observed in the Te 3d and 4d absorption spectra are due to d kf delayed- onset transitions. The closeness in the energy of the a21,, t~,, and t1)1 suggests that the interactions with the ligands are relatively small. The lack of antibonding Te F interactions, especially in a21, which is forbid- den by the molecular symmetry, shows that the ef- fects of the ligand is not a major factor in the con- finement of the f orbital. Finally, the observed absorption peaks are very close in energy to the atomic delayed-onset transition. The d ~kf delayed onset in atomic Te 4d photoionization cross section has been calculated at 10 eV above the threshold [32]. Three strong peaks can be identified from the ex- perimental Te 3d and 4d absorption spectra. In the Te 4d spectrum, the peaks are located at 3, 11 and 22 eV above the threshold. Peaks are found at 3, 10 17 eV in the Te 3d spectrum, The reason for the dis. crepancy in the term values of the corresponding peaks in the 4d and 3d spectrum is unclear. These peaks have been assigned to the d ~f t1,,, a2,, and t2,, transitions in order of increasing energy. In com- parison, the continuum MS X~ calculations predict only two strong features at 10 and 15 eV above the ionization threshold. The energy ordering of the or- bitals t2,, az,, <t,, suggested by the calculations also differs from that of the experimental assignment. 4. Conclusion The analysis of the one-electron orbitals derived from continuum and stabilization MS Xa calcula- tions show that the strong structures observed in the Te d and p post-edge absorption spectra are due to resonant transitions. The localization of the d con- tinuum channels due to an effective potential cre- ated by the strong interactions with the F ligands is responsible for the resonances in the p level spectra. A different explanation for the nature of the tran- sitions observed in the Te d spectra is proposed. Al- though, the assignments to d ~kf resonances are con- sistent with an earlier suggestion [17], the mechanism leading to the localization of the f con- tinuum is more appropriately described as an atomic phenomenon due to penetration of the wavefunction into the barrier created by the centrifugal potential of the Te atom. head.ce:title: The d and f resonances in the core level absorption spectra of TeF6

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Division of Chemistry, National Research Council of Canada, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada K1A 0R9

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The post-edge resonant features observed in the Te p and d core level absorption spectra of TeF6 have been characterized with stabilized bound state and continuum multiple scattering Xα calculations. The nature of the resonances above the Te 4p edge is similar to that observed in SF6 and can be attributed to excitations into quasibound channels with substantial kd character. The localization of the continuum channel is due to strong interactions between the Te d and F p and d orbitals. The origin of the resonances above the Te 4d edge is different. It is better described as a manifestation of the atomic-like d→kf delayed onset as a consequence of the Te centrifugal potential.

ce:other-ref.ce:textref: G.M. Bancroft, K.H. Tan, P.O. Sairaren, S. Aksela and H. Aksela, to be published
N. Kosugi and J.S. Tse, to be published

sb:reference.sb:comment: in press; Abstract - The third chemical congress of north america, PHYS0114, Toronto

sb:title.sb:maintitle: Higher excited states of polyatomic molecules
